stem: Which presentation aligns best with ulnar nerve compression in the cubital tunnel (elbow)?

choices.A: Thenar weakness with paresthesia of digits 1–3
choices.B: Often sensory symptoms predominate in digits 4–5; motor may be mild initially
choices.C: Painless wrist drop with dorsal radial hand numbness
choices.D: Complete loss of thumb opposition with preserved sensation
choices.E: Isolated numbness over the lateral arm

rationale_correct: Slides note cubital tunnel syndrome can present with predominantly sensory deficits initially in the ulnar distribution.

rationale_distractors.A: Median distribution suggests CTS or proximal median lesions.
rationale_distractors.D: Thenar opposition loss is median (recurrent motor).
rationale_distractors.E: Lateral arm cutaneous territory relates to axillary/superior lateral cutaneous nerve.

evidence.citation: Selski D. Nerve Injuries of the Upper Limb (Slides). 2022.
